clinical_study.brief_title: Ambulatory Blood Pressure Measurement in Children With Congenital Urine Flow Obstruction
clinical_study.official_title: Ambulatory Blood Pressure Measurement in Children With Congenital Urine Flow Obstruction

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center

clinical_study.source: University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center

brief_summary.textblock: Children with unilateral congenital urine flow impairment, who require surgery, have abnormal 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure measurements.

intervention.description: Patients will go home with the 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitor to be returned at the clinic after 24 hours.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Children of all races and both sexes including Spanish-speaking under 24 months of age with unilateral hydronephrosis greater than 10-mm in anterior posterior diameter; multicystic-dysplastic kidney on ultrasound examination.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Children over 24 months of age who have undergone surgery and whose parents do not wish to be involved in the study.

responsible_party.organization: University of Texas Southwestern Medical School

clinical_study.keyword: To measure 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure in children who have unilateral hydronephrosis or multicystic-dysplastic kidneys
To compare these blood pressure measurements between the children who require surgical correction and those who do not need surgical correction.
